the crushing grip of your Lord is severe

content.text: Consolation through the People of the Ditch (Verses 1-11)

Allah swears by the sky full of constellations and the Promised Day of Judgment to introduce the story of the **'People of the Ditch' (Ashāb al-Ukhdūd)**. This account condemns the tyrannical rulers who burned believers alive in fire pits. The believers were resented for no reason other than their faith in Allah. Allah promises severe punishment for those who persecute believers unless they repent. The reward for those who believe and do good is Gardens under which rivers flow—the greatest triumph.
Divine Attributes and Sovereignty (Verses 12-22)

Allah reminds the transgressors that His crushing grip is severe. He is the one who originates and resurrects all, yet He is also the All-Forgiving and **All-Loving (Al-Wadūd)**. The destruction of past forces like Pharaoh and Thamūd serves as a historical lesson. Despite their persistent denial, Allah encompassed them from all sides. The Qur'an is declared to be a glorious book, recorded in a Preserved Tablet (Lawh Mahfūz).

quiz.question: What was the only reason the king persecuted the 'People of the Ditch'?
options: They refused to pay taxes.
They tried to take over his kingdom.
They believed in Allah—the Almighty, the Praiseworthy.
They fled from the city.
quiz.correctAnswer: They believed in Allah—the Almighty, the Praiseworthy.

quiz.question: What is the biggest reward promised to those who believe and do good in this Surah?
options: Wealth and a long life.
Gardens under which rivers flow (Jannah).
Fame and glory.
Immediate revenge on their persecutors.
quiz.correctAnswer: Gardens under which rivers flow (Jannah).

quiz.question: What attribute of Allah is mentioned alongside All-Forgiving to emphasize His mercy?
options: Al-Qahhar (The Dominant).
Al-Wadūd (The All-Loving).
Al-Muhyi (The Giver of Life).
Al-Khaliq (The Creator).
quiz.correctAnswer: Al-Wadūd (The All-Loving).

vocab.meaning: a guardian (angel assigned to oversee and record deeds)

content.text: Divine Surveillance and Human Origin (Verses 1-10)

Allah swears by the heaven and the piercing star (At-Tāriq) to affirm a great truth: **'There is no soul without a guardian over it'**. These assigned angels oversee every soul, recording their deeds.

Mankind is commanded to reflect on their creation from a mere spurting fluid emerging from between the backbone and the ribs. This simple origin proves Allah's capability of returning man to life (resurrection). The Day of Judgment will be a time when all secrets will be laid bare, except for the deeds of believers which Allah covered in this world.
The Decisive Qur'an and Patience (Verses 11-17)

Allah swears by the sky and the earth to emphasize the decisive nature of the Qur'an. The Qur'an is a serious message, not something to be taken lightly. Disbelievers are plotting a plot, but Allah reassures the Prophet that He has His own plan. The Prophet and Muslims are advised to be patient and persevere through the adversities posed by disbelievers.

quiz.question: What truth does the oath by the piercing star (At-Tāriq) affirm about every soul?
options: Every soul must be born at night.
Every soul will eventually become a star.
There is no soul without a guardian (angel) over it.
Every soul is created from fire.
quiz.correctAnswer: There is no soul without a guardian (angel) over it.

quiz.question: The difference in the Qur'an and the disbelievers' plots is that:
options: The Qur'an is a humorous joke, and their plot is serious.
The Qur'an is a decisive, serious statement, and their plot is temporary, which Allah has a counter-plan for.
The Qur'an is meant only for scholars, and their plot is for the common people.
The Qur'an is only historical, and their plot is futuristic.
quiz.correctAnswer: The Qur'an is a decisive, serious statement, and their plot is temporary, which Allah has a counter-plan for.

quiz.question: On the Day when secrets will be laid bare, what will Allah honor and cover for the believers?
options: Their hidden wealth.
Their place of residence.
The secrets of their hearts that Allah had already covered in the world.
Their family lineage.
quiz.correctAnswer: The secrets of their hearts that Allah had already covered in the world.

content.text: The Command to Glorify and Divine Assurance (Verses 1-8)

The Surah begins with the command to **'Glorify the Name of your Lord, the Most High'**. Allah is praised as the One who perfectly created, fashioned, ordained and guided. He also controls the cycle of growth and decay in nature, reducing green pasture to withered chaff.

Allah provides assurance to the Prophet (PBUH) who feared forgetting the revelation. Allah promises: 'We will have you recite the Quran, O Prophet, so you will not forget any of it' and that He will facilitate for him the Way of Ease.
The Outcome of Adherence (Verses 9-19)

The Prophet's duty is to always remind people with the Qur'an. Those who fear Allah will be mindful, while the most wretched will shun it and burn in the greatest Fire, where they will neither die nor live.

True winners are those who continuously purify their hearts, remember the Name of their Lord, and pray. Despite the Hereafter being far better and more lasting, many humans prefer the fleeting life of this world. This core message was also mentioned in the earlier Scriptures of Abraham and Moses.

quiz.question: What fear did the Prophet (PBUH) have that Allah addressed in Surah Al-A'la?
options: The fear of persecution from the Quraysh.
The fear of forgetting the revelation (Qur'an).
The fear of not having enough followers.
The fear of his wife leaving him.
quiz.correctAnswer: The fear of forgetting the revelation (Qur'an).

quiz.question: What is the key reason given in the Surah for why people should prefer the Hereafter over this worldly life?
options: The Hereafter is closer in time.
The Hereafter is easier to achieve.
The Hereafter is far better and more lasting.
The Hereafter is only for the very wealthy.
quiz.correctAnswer: The Hereafter is far better and more lasting.

quiz.question: Which two previous Prophets are mentioned as having received the same core message as the one in this Surah?
options: Noah and Lot.
David and Solomon.
Abraham and Moses.
Adam and Idris.
quiz.correctAnswer: Abraham and Moses.

vocab.meaning: foul, thorny shrub (painful food of Hell)
no idle talk will be heard

content.text: The Overwhelming Day and the Fate of the Evil (Verses 1-7)

The 'Overwhelming Event' (Al-Ghashiyah) is the Day of Judgment. The evil people will come humbled, looking exhausted and tired (A'milatun Nāṣibah). They will burn in a scorching Fire, forced to drink from a scalding spring, and fed a painful thorny shrub (Ḍarī') that neither nourishes nor satisfies hunger.
The Bliss of the Righteous (Verses 8-16)

The good people will come joyful, with faces glowing with bliss, fully pleased with their striving, having earned Jannah in an elevated Garden. Jannah is a peaceful place where they will hear no idle talk. They will have running springs, raised thrones, cups, cushions, and splendid carpets.
Signs in Creation and Prophetic Duty (Verses 17-26)

Allah invites people to reflect on four simple creations that prove His power: the camel (a very special, masterfully created animal), the sky (raised high), the mountains (firmly set up), and the earth (leveled out). The Prophet (PBUH) is commanded to continue reminding people of Allah, as his duty is only to remind, not to compel them to believe. Those who turn away and persist in disbelief will face the major punishment, as their return and reckoning are with Allah alone.

quiz.question: The faces of the evil people on the Day of Judgment are described as having what physical state?
options: Glowing with bliss.
Smiling and contented.
Totally overburdened, exhausted, and downcast.
Normal and calm.
quiz.correctAnswer: Totally overburdened, exhausted, and downcast.

quiz.question: What is unique about the food of the people in Hell (Ḍarī')?
options: It is delicious but scarce.
It is a thorny shrub that neither nourishes nor satisfies hunger.
It is simple bread and water.
It is only available to some people.
quiz.correctAnswer: It is a thorny shrub that neither nourishes nor satisfies hunger.

quiz.question: What is the key takeaway for a Muslim's duty regarding the rejection of the message?
options: To compel people to believe using force.
To stop reminding people entirely if they reject it.
To continue reminding people without worrying about who accepts it, as reckoning is with Allah.
To only remind those who are rich and powerful.
quiz.correctAnswer: To continue reminding people without worrying about who accepts it, as reckoning is with Allah.

vocab.meaning: the ten nights (last 10 of Ramadan or first 10 of Dhul-Hijjah)
with their great stature (referring to the people of 'Ad)
I had sent forth 'something good for my true' life

content.text: Oaths and Historical Lessons (Verses 1-14)

Allah swears by the dawn and the ten nights (a period of great virtue) to emphasize the importance of the warnings that follow. Lessons are drawn from the destruction of past tribes: 'Ad (who had great stature), Thamūd (who carved homes into rocks), and Pharaoh (of mighty structures). They all transgressed and spread corruption, resulting in Allah unleashing a severe scourge of punishment. Allah is truly vigilant (Bi-al-Mirsād).
Critique of Man's Attitudes (Verses 15-20)

The Surah critiques man's inconsistent attitude toward divine tests: when tested with generosity, he boasts he is honored; but when tested with limited provision, he protests that Allah has 'undeservedly humiliated' him. This leads to four bad character traits that are condemned: not being gracious to orphans, not encouraging the feeding of the poor, greedily consuming others' inheritance, and loving wealth fervently.
The Ultimate Invitation (Verses 21-30)

On the Day of Judgment, when the earth is crushed and Hell is brought forth, the disbeliever will remember their sins and cry, 'I wish I had sent forth [something good] for my [true] life'. Allah's punishment will be severe and just.

The Surah culminates with Allah's personal invitation to the believer's heart: 'O tranquil soul! Return to your Lord, well pleased with Him and well pleasing [to Him]. So join My servants, and enter My Paradise.'.

quiz.question: What is the key lesson drawn from the destruction of nations like 'Ad and Thamūd in this Surah?
options: That wealth ensures safety.
That Allah will never punish a powerful nation.
That transgression and corruption lead to severe divine punishment.
That they were too humble.
quiz.correctAnswer: That transgression and corruption lead to severe divine punishment.

quiz.question: How does man typically react when Allah tests him by limiting his provision?
options: He boasts he is honored.
He praises Allah more deeply.
He protests that Allah has 'undeservedly humiliated' him.
He only seeks charity from others.
quiz.correctAnswer: He protests that Allah has 'undeservedly humiliated' him.

quiz.question: What four bad character traits are specifically condemned in the second part of the Surah?
options: Being too quiet, eating too little, sleeping too much, and reading too much.
Not honoring the orphan, not feeding the poor, greedily consuming inheritance, and loving wealth fervently.
Ignoring the sun, moon, and stars.
Failing to travel and explore the world.
quiz.correctAnswer: Not honoring the orphan, not feeding the poor, greedily consuming inheritance, and loving wealth fervently.

vocab.meaning: the two ways of right and wrong

content.text: Man Created for Struggle (Verses 1-10)

Allah swears by Mecca (The City) to establish the fundamental truth: humankind was created in **constant struggle (Kabad)**. The Surah challenges the arrogant person who boasts of squandering enormous wealth, thinking no one has power over or sees them. Allah reminds man of the blessings He gave: two eyes, a tongue, and two lips, and the innate guidance to distinguish between right and wrong (Al-Najdayn).
The Challenging Path (Verses 11-16)

The Surah asks why man has not attempted the challenging path of goodness (Al-'Aqabah). This path involves difficult deeds that go against selfish desires. Examples include: **freeing a slave**, **giving food in times of famine** to an orphaned relative, or a poor person in distress.

The successful ones (People of the Right) are those who have faith and urge each other to perseverance (Sabr) and compassion (Marhamah). Those who deny Allah's signs are the People of the Left, and the Fire will be sealed over them.

quiz.question: What is the meaning of the phrase 'We have created humankind in constant struggle' (Fī Kabad)?
options: That life is always easy and peaceful.
That humans are created for toil and struggle.
That humans are meant to hoard all their wealth.
That only the Prophets struggled in life.
quiz.correctAnswer: That humans are created for toil and struggle.

quiz.question: What is the 'challenging path of goodness' (Al-'Aqabah) exemplified by?
options: Boasting about one's wealth.
Fleeing from the city of Makkah.
Freeing a slave and feeding the poor during famine.
Ignoring all advice from others.
quiz.correctAnswer: Freeing a slave and feeding the poor during famine.

quiz.question: The successful people (of the right) are characterized by having faith and urging each other to what two virtues?
options: Rivalry and ambition.
Wealth and status.
Perseverance (Sabr) and compassion (Marhamah).
War and conquest.
quiz.correctAnswer: Perseverance (Sabr) and compassion (Marhamah).

vocab.meaning: By the sun and its brightness

content.text: Cosmic Oaths and The Soul's Inspiration (Verses 1-10)

Allah swears by several pairs of cosmic opposites—the sun/moon, day/night, heaven/earth—to emphasize the divine origin of the subsequent message. The ultimate oath is by the soul, which Allah fashioned and inspired with the knowledge of both its **wickedness (Fūjūr) and its righteousness (Taqwā)**.
This leads to the Surah's core conclusion: **'Successful indeed is the one who purifies their soul, and doomed is the one who corrupts it!'**.
The Example of Thamūd (Verses 11-15)

The tribe of Thamūd is used as a stark historical example. They rejected the truth out of arrogance. The most wicked among them was roused to kill the she-camel, which Prophet Saleh had warned them not to disturb. Because they defied him and slaughtered the camel, their Lord crushed them all, leveling them to the ground. Allah has no fear of consequences in carrying out His justice.

quiz.question: What is the ultimate choice and source of success/failure mentioned in this Surah?
options: Achieving a high education.
Choosing to purify or corrupt one's soul.
Finding a great source of wealth.
Building a large army.
quiz.correctAnswer: Choosing to purify or corrupt one's soul.

quiz.question: The word 'Fūjūr' (wickedness) and 'Taqwā' (righteousness) are mentioned to show that the human soul is inspired with what?
options: Only goodness.
Only evil.
The knowledge of both its wickedness and its righteousness.
The ability to fly.
quiz.correctAnswer: The knowledge of both its wickedness and its righteousness.

quiz.question: What act led to the destruction of the tribe of Thamūd in this Surah?
options: They refused to build homes in the rocks.
They worshiped the moon.
They defied their prophet and slaughtered the she-camel.
They refused to travel.
quiz.correctAnswer: They defied their prophet and slaughtered the she-camel.

vocab.meaning: the ends you strive for are diverse
firmly believes in the finest reward

content.text: The Diversity of Human Effort (Verses 1-4)
Allah swears by opposites—night/day and male/female—to emphasize the diversity in human actions and goals.
The Two Paths (Verses 5-11)
The Surah contrasts the paths of two individuals:

items: **The Righteous:** One who is charitable, mindful of Allah, and believes in the finest reward (Al-Husnā). Allah will facilitate for them the **Way of Ease**.

**The Wretched:** One who is stingy (Bakhil), denies the finest reward, and is indifferent to Allah. Allah will facilitate for them the **path of hardship**. Their wealth will be of no benefit when they tumble into Hell.

content.text: Allah affirms that guidance and ownership of this life and the next belong to Him. The truly righteous donate solely to purify themselves and seek the pleasure of Allah, not in return for favors. They will certainly be pleased with their reward.

quiz.question: What is the 'finest reward' (Al-Husnā) that the righteous firmly believe in?
options: The ability to travel and see the world.
Paradise and the Hereafter.
Immediate wealth in this life.
The possession of fine horses.
quiz.correctAnswer: Paradise and the Hereafter.

quiz.question: For those who are stingy and deny the finest reward, what is the consequence of their wealth?
options: It will ensure they live forever.
It will be used to help others.
It will be of no benefit to them when they tumble into Hell.
It will continue to increase until they die.
quiz.correctAnswer: It will be of no benefit to them when they tumble into Hell.

quiz.question: What is the defining characteristic of the donation made by the righteous to purify themselves?
options: It is done to receive thanks from others.
It is done in return for someone else's favors.
It is done only to seek the pleasure of their Lord, the Most High.
It is done publicly to encourage others.
quiz.correctAnswer: It is done only to seek the pleasure of their Lord, the Most High.

vocab.meaning: Your Lord has not abandoned you, nor has He become hateful of you
And proclaim the blessings of your Lord

content.text: Divine Consolation and Assurance (Verses 1-5)

This Surah was revealed when revelation paused, leading disbelievers to mock the Prophet (PBUH). Allah swore by the morning sunlight and the night to reassure the Prophet that **'Your Lord... has not abandoned you, nor has He become hateful of you'**. He promises that the Hereafter will be far better, and He will give the Prophet so much that he will be pleased.
Recounting Past Blessings (Verses 6-8)
As an antidote to grief, Allah reminds the Prophet of His past blessings: sheltering him as an orphan, guiding him when he was unguided, and providing for him when he was needy.
Commands of Gratitude (Verses 9-11)

In response to these blessings, the Prophet (and all believers) are commanded to treat the vulnerable with compassion: **'So do not oppress the orphan, nor repulse the beggar. And proclaim the blessings of your Lord.'**.

quiz.question: What was the main purpose of Surah Ad-Duha's revelation?
options: To establish the rules of prayer.
To console the Prophet (PBUH) after a pause in revelation and assure him of divine favor.
To command a new military campaign.
To describe the signs of the Day of Judgment.
quiz.correctAnswer: To console the Prophet (PBUH) after a pause in revelation and assure him of divine favor.

quiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a command of gratitude given in the final verses of the Surah?
options: To proclaim the blessings of the Lord.
To oppress the orphan.
Not to repulse the beggar.
To reflect on Allah's past blessings.
quiz.correctAnswer: To oppress the orphan.

quiz.question: What is the Prophet (PBUH) assured will be 'far better' for him than this present life?
options: His fame among the Arabs.
The next life (the Hereafter).
The immediate end of all persecution.
The wealth he will accumulate.
quiz.correctAnswer: The next life (the Hereafter).

vocab.meaning: turn to your Lord alone with hope

content.text: Divine Honors and Relief (Verses 1-4)

This Surah was revealed when the Prophet (PBUH) was experiencing sadness and discouragement. Allah reminds him of the blessings already bestowed: uplifting (purifying) his heart, relieving him of the burden that weighed heavily on his back, and elevating his renown.
The Principle of Ease (Verses 5-6)

Allah emphasizes a golden life principle that relief will follow struggle, repeating it for certainty and reassurance: **'So, surely with hardship comes ease. Surely with that hardship comes more ease.'**.
The Command for Continuous Devotion (Verses 7-8)

The final instruction guides the believer to respond with continuous effort: **'So once you have fulfilled your duty, strive [in devotion], turning to your Lord alone with hope.'**. This teaches a Muslim to move seamlessly from one act of worship to the next.

quiz.question: What is the key principle repeated twice in Surah Ash-Sharh for emphasis?
options: With wealth comes happiness.
With every sun comes the moon.
With hardship comes ease.
With every question comes an answer.
quiz.correctAnswer: With hardship comes ease.

quiz.question: The phrase 'uplifted your heart for you' refers to what divine action for the Prophet (PBUH)?
options: Healing a physical ailment.
Purifying his soul and preparing him for prophethood.
Giving him immediate victory in battle.
Removing his financial debts.
quiz.correctAnswer: Purifying his soul and preparing him for prophethood.

quiz.question: What are believers commanded to do immediately after fulfilling one duty/task?
options: To take a long, extended rest.
To strive in devotion and turn to their Lord alone with hope.
To look for worldly employment.
To seek assistance from others.
quiz.correctAnswer: To strive in devotion and turn to their Lord alone with hope.

vocab.meaning: the lowest of the low in Hell
the most just of all judges

content.text: Oaths on Sacred Lands (Verses 1-3)

Allah swears by four significant locations, symbolizing the connection among the Abrahamic faiths: the fig and the olive (referencing the lands of the Prophets, Jerusalem and Syria), Mount Sinai (where Moses received the Law), and Makkah (the secure city).
Man's Potential and Final Destiny (Verses 4-8)

These oaths lead to the declaration that Allah **'created humans in the best form (Ahsani Taqweem)'**, giving them the ability to make choices. Those who believe and do good deeds will have a never-ending reward (Jannah).

Those who fail to believe and do good will be reduced to the lowest of the low in Hell. The Surah concludes by challenging the denier of the Judgment and affirming Allah as the most just of all judges.

quiz.question: What declaration does Allah make about the creation of humans in Surah At-Tin?
options: That man was created from pure light.
That man was created in the best form (Ahsani Taqweem).
That man was created only to accumulate wealth.
That man was created without free will.
quiz.correctAnswer: That man was created in the best form (Ahsani Taqweem).

quiz.question: The places sworn by (Fig, Olive, Mount Sinai, Mecca) symbolize what in this Surah?
options: The four cardinal directions.
The different levels of heaven.
The connection and brotherhood among the Abrahamic religions and their prophets.
The major trading posts in Arabia.
quiz.correctAnswer: The connection and brotherhood among the Abrahamic religions and their prophets.

quiz.question: What two things are required to receive the 'never-ending reward' and avoid being reduced to the 'lowest of the low'?
options: Giving small kindnesses and having a long life.
Belief and good deeds.
Ignoring the poor and mocking others.
Accumulating great wealth and power.
quiz.correctAnswer: Belief and good deeds.

vocab.meaning: Read/Recite (The first command of the Qur'an)

content.text: The First Revelation: Knowledge and Creation (Verses 1-5)

This Surah contains the first verses ever revealed to the Prophet (PBUH). The command is **'Read (Iqra!) in the Name of your Lord Who created'**. It establishes the foundation of Islam: Allah created man from a clinging clot, and He is the Most Generous Who taught man by the pen, emphasizing the importance of knowledge.
Man's Arrogance and the Opponent (Verses 6-19)
Humans tend to transgress and exceed all bounds (Yaṭghā) when they falsely think they are self-sufficient (Istaghnā). The ultimate return of all is to Allah.

The Surah focuses on the antagonist (Abu Jahl) who opposed the Prophet and tried to prevent him from praying. Allah warns this opponent of severe consequences, threatening to drag him by his 'lying, sinful forelock'. Allah instructs the Prophet to disregard this opposition, never obey him, and instead **'prostrate and draw near [to Allah]'**.

quiz.question: What two concepts are established as foundational in the first five verses of the Qur'an?
options: War and peace.
Creation of man and the importance of knowledge and the pen.
Trade and commerce.
Fame and reputation.
quiz.correctAnswer: Creation of man and the importance of knowledge and the pen.

quiz.question: What state causes man to 'exceed all bounds' (Yaṭghā)?
options: Having too little wealth.
Thinking they are self-sufficient and don't need Allah.
Being too charitable to the poor.
Working too hard during the day.
quiz.correctAnswer: Thinking they are self-sufficient and don't need Allah.

quiz.question: What is the final instruction given to the Prophet (PBUH) in response to his opponent's threats?
options: To fight the opponent immediately.
To flee to a new city.
To continue to prostrate and draw near to Allah.
To call upon his tribal associates for help.
quiz.correctAnswer: To continue to prostrate and draw near to Allah.

content.text: The Immense Value of the Night of Decree (Verses 1-5)
This short Surah highlights the immense significance of **Laylat al-Qadr (The Night of Glory/Decree)**. The Qur'an was sent down on this blessed night.
The central message is its overwhelming merit: the Night of Glory is **'better than a thousand months'** in terms of reward, equivalent to approximately 83 years of continuous worship.
On this night, the angels and the Holy Spirit (Jibreel) descend by Allah's permission for every decreed matter. The night is characterized by being entirely 'peace until the break of dawn'.

quiz.question: What is the meaning of the statement, 'The Night of Glory is better than a thousand months'?
options: The night lasts longer than 1,000 days.
Worshipping on this single night yields reward equivalent to over 83 years of worship.
Only 1,000 people will witness this night.
It is the anniversary of 1,000 historical events.
quiz.correctAnswer: Worshipping on this single night yields reward equivalent to over 83 years of worship.

quiz.question: Besides the angels, who is specifically mentioned as descending on the Night of Glory?
options: The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).
The Holy Spirit (Ar-Rūh), or Jibreel.
All righteous people from Earth.
The past generations of prophets.
quiz.correctAnswer: The Holy Spirit (Ar-Rūh), or Jibreel.

quiz.question: In the context of the revelation, what occurred on Laylat al-Qadr?
options: The Earth was split open.
The entire Qur'an was sent down to the lowest heaven and the first verses were revealed to the Prophet.
The Ka'bah was destroyed.
The rules for fasting were established.
quiz.correctAnswer: The entire Qur'an was sent down to the lowest heaven and the first verses were revealed to the Prophet.

vocab.meaning: People of the Book (Jews and Christians)
The Clear Proof (Prophet Muhammad and the Qur'an)

content.text: The Clear Proof Arrives (Verses 1-4)

The Surah addresses the disbelievers from the People of the Book and the polytheists. They claimed they would not desist from disbelief until the Clear Proof (Al-Bayyinah) came. The Proof arrived as a Messenger (Prophet Muhammad, PBUH) from Allah, reciting scrolls of utmost purity. The division among the People of the Book occurred *after* this Clear Proof came.
The Core Command and Two Destinies (Verses 5-8)

The universal command in all previous scriptures was simple: to worship Allah alone with **sincere devotion (Ikhlās)**, establish prayer, and pay alms-tax (Zakāt). That is the upright Way (Dīn al-Qayyimah).

The disbelievers are the **worst of all beings** (Sharru al-Bariyyah) and will be in Hell forever. Conversely, those who believe and do good are the **best of all beings** (Khayru al-Bariyyah). Their reward is eternal Gardens of Eternity, where Allah is pleased with them and they are pleased with Him.

quiz.question: Who does the term 'Al-Bayyinah' (The Clear Proof) refer to in this Surah?
options: The new temple in Makkah.
The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the Qur'an.
The sign of the splitting of the moon.
The rules for trade and commerce.
quiz.correctAnswer: The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the Qur'an.

quiz.question: What is the fate of those who believe and do good deeds according to Surah Al-Bayyinah?
options: They will be the worst of all beings.
They will have a temporary stay in Paradise.
They will be the best of all beings and receive eternal Gardens of Eternity.
They will be given an opportunity to return to the world.
quiz.correctAnswer: They will be the best of all beings and receive eternal Gardens of Eternity.

quiz.question: What is one of the major rewards for the righteous mentioned in the final verse?
options: Becoming kings on Earth.
Being able to travel to every planet.
The pleasure and contentment of Allah and their being pleased with Him.
A long, healthy life on Earth.
quiz.correctAnswer: The pleasure and contentment of Allah and their being pleased with Him.

vocab.meaning: the earth is shaken in its ultimate quaking
its news/everything that happened on it
people will proceed in separate groups

content.text: The Earth's Ultimate Quaking (Verses 1-5)

The Day of Judgment will begin with a massive earthquake, causing the earth to shake violently and throw out all its contents, including treasures and dead bodies. Humanity will cry out, 'What is wrong with it?'.
On that Day, the Earth will speak and **'recount everything'** (report its news), testifying to all events that happened upon it, having been commanded by Allah to do so.
Precise Accountability (Verses 6-8)

People will proceed in separate groups (Ashtātan) to be shown the consequences of their deeds. The Surah concludes with the fundamental principle of Divine Justice: every action, no matter how small, will be accounted for.

items: Whoever does an **atom's weight of good** will see it.
Whoever does an **atom's weight of evil** will see it.

quiz.question: What surprising action will the Earth take on the Day of Judgment?
options: It will fly into the sky.
It will stop rotating permanently.
It will speak and recount everything that happened upon it.
It will apologize for all the bad deeds done on it.
quiz.correctAnswer: It will speak and recount everything that happened upon it.

quiz.question: The final verses of the Surah emphasize that every action, no matter how small, will be accounted for. What unit of measurement is used to stress this point?
options: A mountain's weight.
An ocean's weight.
An atom's weight.
A kilogram.
quiz.correctAnswer: An atom's weight.

quiz.question: Why will people proceed in 'separate groups' (Ashtātan) on that Day?
options: To hide their deeds from others.
To find their family members.
To be shown the consequences of their individual deeds.
To travel to a new location.
quiz.correctAnswer: To be shown the consequences of their individual deeds.

vocab.meaning: truly extreme in their love of 'worldly' gains/wealth
the contents of the graves will be spilled out
the secrets of the hearts will be laid bare

content.text: Oaths of War Horses and Man's Ingratitude (Verses 1-8)

Allah swears by the loyalty and ferocity of war horses—those that gallop, strike sparks, launch raids at dawn, and penetrate enemy lines. This serves as a contrast to the human characteristic that follows: **'Surely humankind is ungrateful (Kanūd) to their Lord'**. Man attests to this ingratitude and is extreme in their love and obsession with worldly gains.
The Unveiling of Secrets (Verses 9-11)

People often forget there will be a Day of Judgment when the contents of the graves will be spilled out and, more critically, **'the secrets of the hearts will be laid bare'**. Allah is All-Aware of them on that Day.

quiz.question: The oaths by the war horses in the opening verses are used to highlight which negative quality of mankind?
options: Their laziness.
Their fear of combat.
Their ungratefulness (Kanūd) to their Lord.
Their mastery of horsemanship.
quiz.correctAnswer: Their ungratefulness (Kanūd) to their Lord.

quiz.question: What does the phrase 'the secrets of the hearts will be laid bare' imply about accountability?
options: Only outward actions will be judged.
All hidden intentions, thoughts, and deeds will be exposed.
Only the actions of the horses will be revealed.
That the heart will stop beating on that Day.
quiz.correctAnswer: All hidden intentions, thoughts, and deeds will be exposed.

quiz.question: What 'Khayr' (good) are humans described as being extreme in their love for?
options: The love of seeking knowledge.
The love of worldly gains/wealth.
The love of fasting and prayer.
The love of solitude.
quiz.correctAnswer: The love of worldly gains/wealth.

vocab.meaning: whose scale is heavy (with good deeds)

content.text: The Chaos of the Striking Disaster (Verses 1-5)

The Surah begins by emphasizing the severity and surprise of the Day of Judgment, calling it **'The Striking Disaster' (Al-Qāri'ah)**. The chaos is described in vivid terms: people will be like scattered moths, and the mountains, once firm, will become like carded wool.
The Final Verdict (Verses 6-11)
The core message is the decisive weighing of deeds (Mawāzīn):

items: **Heavy Scales:** Those whose scale is heavy with good deeds will be in a life of bliss (Jannah).
**Light Scales:** Those whose scale is light will have their home in **Al-Hāwiyah** (The Abyss), which is described as a scorching Fire.
Deeds determine one's qualification for Heaven or Hell.

content.text: The Day of Judgment will be surprising and chaotic.

quiz.question: How are people described as appearing on the Day of Judgment in this Surah?
options: Like firmly set mountains.
Like perfectly aligned soldiers.
Like scattered moths.
Like powerful kings.
quiz.correctAnswer: Like scattered moths.

quiz.question: What is the ultimate destination for those whose scale of deeds is 'light'?
options: A temporary holding place.
Al-Hāwiyah (The Abyss/Scorching Fire).
The Gardens of Bliss.
They return to Earth.
quiz.correctAnswer: Al-Hāwiyah (The Abyss/Scorching Fire).

quiz.question: What primary event will determine a person's eternal fate in Surah Al-Qari'ah?
options: The size of their wealth.
The speed of their prayer.
The weighing of their deeds (Mawāzīn).
Their mastery of the Arabic language.
quiz.correctAnswer: The weighing of their deeds (Mawāzīn).

sections.sectionTitle: Surah At-Takathur (Rivalry in Worldly Increase, Surah 102)

vocab.meaning: Competition for more 'gains diverts you from Allah
the eye of certainty (seeing something with one's own eyes)

content.text: The Distraction of Worldly Rivalry (Verses 1-4)

This Surah delivers a sharp warning: **'Competition for more [worldly] gains (At-Takāthur) diverts you from Allah'**. This obsession with rivalry and collecting more wealth or status continues until man visits the graves (i.e., until they die). Allah assures them they will soon come to know the truth of the Hereafter.
The Certainty and Accountability (Verses 5-8)
The Surah addresses the three levels of certainty:

items: **Knowledge of Certainty (Ilm al-Yaqīn):** What they should have known in life.
**The Eye of Certainty (Ayn al-Yaqīn):** What they will see when they witness Hellfire.
**Haqq al-Yaqīn (True Certainty):** The experience of the reality.

content.text: On that Day, they will definitely be questioned about the worldly pleasures (An-Na'īm) they enjoyed, and they will realize their mistake.

quiz.question: What is the primary distraction that diverts people from Allah, as condemned in this Surah?
options: Excessive prayer.
Rivalry and competition for more worldly gains (At-Takāthur).
Seeking knowledge of the universe.
Helping the less fortunate.
quiz.correctAnswer: Rivalry and competition for more worldly gains (At-Takāthur).

quiz.question: The pursuit of 'more' continues for mankind until they reach what point?
options: Until they build a great castle.
Until they travel across the sea.
Until they end up in their graves.
Until they master a new language.
quiz.correctAnswer: Until they end up in their graves.

quiz.question: What will people be questioned about on the Day of Judgment, according to the final verse?
options: The number of books they wrote.
The worldly pleasures (An-Na'īm) they enjoyed.
The names of their children.
The types of animals they owned.
quiz.correctAnswer: The worldly pleasures (An-Na'īm) they enjoyed.

vocab.meaning: urge each other to the truth

content.text: The Formula for Salvation (Verses 1-3)
Allah swears by Time (Al-'Asr), emphasizing its importance and the fleeting nature of life. He declares that 'Surely humanity is in [grave] loss'.
The only exceptions to this universal loss are those who fulfill four necessary, interconnected conditions (the formula for success):

items: **1. Faith (Iman):** Believe.
**2. Righteous Deeds (Amal as-Sālihāt):** Do good.
**3. Mutual Urging to the Truth (Al-Haqq):** Urge each other to the truth.
**4. Mutual Urging to Perseverance (As-Sabr):** Urge each other to perseverance and patience.

content.text: The ultimate success is determined by one's faith and actions, and patience and perseverance are crucial in upholding truth and righteousness.

quiz.question: What is the universal state of mankind, according to this Surah, without the four exceptions?
options: In a state of great joy.
In a state of great wealth.
In a state of grave loss.
In a state of constant sleep.
quiz.correctAnswer: In a state of grave loss.

quiz.question: Which one of the following is NOT one of the four conditions for salvation mentioned in Surah Al-Asr?
options: Having faith.
Doing good deeds.
Urging each other to acquire wealth.
Urging each other to perseverance/patience.
quiz.correctAnswer: Urging each other to acquire wealth.

quiz.question: What does the oath 'By the passage of time' emphasize?
options: The permanence of life.
The importance and fleeting nature of time.
The need to ignore the past.
The certainty of future technology.
quiz.correctAnswer: The importance and fleeting nature of time.

content.text: Condemnation of Mockery and Greed (Verses 1-3)

Allah issues a severe condemnation ('Woe!') to every backbiter and slanderer (Humazah Lumazah). This is coupled with the condemnation of those who amass wealth greedily, counting it repeatedly. They are deluded, thinking their wealth will grant them immortality or independence from Allah.
The Punishment of The Crusher (Verses 4-9)

Such people will be tossed into **Al-Hutamah (The Crusher)**. This is Allah's kindled Fire, which is unique because it will penetrate and rage over the hearts (Al-Af'idah)—the source of their corrupt desires, envy, and greed. The Fire will be sealed over them with long braces.

quiz.question: What is the specific name of the Hellfire mentioned in Surah Al-Humazah?
options: Al-Qāri'ah.
Al-Hutamah (The Crusher).
As-Sākhkhah.
An-Naba.
quiz.correctAnswer: Al-Hutamah (The Crusher).

quiz.question: Why do the hoarders of wealth think their riches will save them?
options: They believe wealth will make them immortal.
They believe money can buy forgiveness.
They believe they can bribe the angels.
They believe wealth can extinguish the Fire.
quiz.correctAnswer: They believe wealth will make them immortal.

quiz.question: What part of the body will the Hellfire target in Al-Hutamah?
options: The hands and feet.
The eyes and ears.
The heart (Al-Af'idah).
The skin and hair.
quiz.correctAnswer: The heart (Al-Af'idah).

vocab.meaning: the Army of the Elephant (Abraha's army)

content.text: Divine Protection of the Ka'bah (Verses 1-5)

The Surah recalls the powerful historical event of the Army of the Elephant, led by Abraha, who attempted to destroy the Ka'bah. Allah asks, 'Have you not seen [O Prophet] how your Lord dealt with the Army of the Elephant?'

Allah frustrated their scheme, defeating the mighty army by sending weak creatures—flocks of birds (Abābīl)—that pelted them with stones of baked clay. The army was left like chewed-up straw. This event is a sign that Allah protects His sacred places and handles His enemies in His own way.

quiz.question: Who was the leader of the Army of the Elephant?
options: Abu Lahab.
Abraha, the governor of Yemen.
A Roman emperor.
The Prophet's grandfather.
quiz.correctAnswer: Abraha, the governor of Yemen.

quiz.question: How did Allah destroy the Army of the Elephant?
options: By a massive flood.
By a huge earthquake.
By sending flocks of birds (Abābīl) with stones of baked clay.
By blinding the elephants.
quiz.correctAnswer: By sending flocks of birds (Abābīl) with stones of baked clay.

quiz.question: What primary lesson is drawn from the event of the Army of the Elephant?
options: That elephants are powerful war animals.
That humans should always travel in groups.
That Allah protects His sacred places and frustrates the schemes of His enemies.
That birds are the strongest creatures on Earth.
quiz.correctAnswer: That Allah protects His sacred places and frustrates the schemes of His enemies.

vocab.meaning: the favour of making Quraysh habitually secure
trading caravan in the winter and summer
the Lord of this Sacred House (the Ka'bah)

content.text: Gratitude for Divine Favors (Verses 1-4)

This Surah reminds the tribe of Quraysh of the blessings they enjoy due to their hosting of the Ka'bah. Allah provided them with security in their trading caravans to Yemen (winter) and Syria (summer), despite living in a resource-scarce area.

In return for these great blessings, the command is simple and fundamental: **'let them worship the Lord of this Sacred House, Who has fed them against hunger and made them secure against fear'**. Protection from hunger and fear are essential for a society's flourishing.

quiz.question: What is the specific command given to the Quraysh tribe in return for their security and prosperity?
options: To travel only in the summer.
To move the Ka'bah to a safer location.
To worship the Lord of the Sacred House (the Ka'bah).
To establish a new form of currency.
quiz.correctAnswer: To worship the Lord of the Sacred House (the Ka'bah).

quiz.question: What two key benefits did the Quraysh enjoy that are highlighted as favors from Allah?
options: Great military power and vast territory.
Exemption from fasting and prayer.
Being fed against hunger and made secure against fear.
The ability to fly and swim well.
quiz.correctAnswer: Being fed against hunger and made secure against fear.

quiz.question: What specific human effort does this Surah mention that benefited the Quraysh?
options: Their mastery of science.
Their peaceful trade caravans in the winter and summer.
Their ability to read and write.
Their building of great pyramids.
quiz.correctAnswer: Their peaceful trade caravans in the winter and summer.

content.text: The Traits of the Denier (Verses 1-7)
The Surah starkly links the denial of the Day of Judgment (Dīn) to negative social behavior and insincere worship. The one who denies Dīn is characterized by five negative traits:

items: **1. Repulsing the orphan**.
**2. Not encouraging the feeding of the poor**.
**3. Being unmindful/negligent of their prayers (Sāhūn)**.
**4. Showing off (Riyā')**.
**5. Refusing to give even the simplest aid or small kindnesses (Al-Mā'ūn)**.

content.text: The core message is that spiritual worship (Prayer) is inseparable from social ethics (compassion and charity). Woe (Wail) is promised to the hypocrites who pray without mindfulness.

quiz.question: What does 'Sāhūn' (Verse 4) refer to in the context of prayer?
options: Praying five times a day.
Reciting the Qur'an in a loud voice.
Being unmindful or negligent of their prayer.
Praying only on Fridays.
quiz.correctAnswer: Being unmindful or negligent of their prayer.

quiz.question: The denial of the Day of Judgment manifests itself in which of the following social behaviors?
options: Encouraging the feeding of the poor.
Repulsing the orphan.
Being a devout Muslim who fasts regularly.
Speaking only the truth.
quiz.correctAnswer: Repulsing the orphan.

quiz.question: What is the meaning of 'Al-Mā'ūn'?
options: Great acts of devotion like Pilgrimage.
Refusing to participate in military campaigns.
The simplest aid or small kindnesses.
The wealth accumulated by the rich.
quiz.correctAnswer: The simplest aid or small kindnesses.

vocab.meaning: abundant goodness (A special river/fountain in Paradise)
So pray and sacrifice to your Lord alone

content.text: Divine Grant and Consolation (Verses 1-3)

This Surah was revealed to comfort the Prophet (PBUH) who was being mocked by his opponents (like Abu Lahab) for having no male offspring, calling him **'Al-Abtar' (cut off)**. Allah assures him that He has granted him abundant goodness (Al-Kawthar).

The command in response is gratitude and sincere worship: **'So pray and sacrifice to your Lord alone.'**. The Surah concludes by reversing the insult: the one who hates the Prophet is truly the one who is cut off from any goodness and legacy.

quiz.question: What is the meaning of 'Al-Kawthar'?
options: A title of leadership.
The name of the Prophet's son.
Abundant goodness, including a special River/Fountain in Paradise.
The name of the shortest Surah.
quiz.correctAnswer: Abundant goodness, including a special River/Fountain in Paradise.

quiz.question: What act of worship is the Prophet (PBUH) specifically commanded to do in response to the gift of Al-Kawthar?
options: To fast every day.
To travel and leave Makkah.
To pray and offer sacrifice to his Lord alone.
To write a new book of poetry.
quiz.correctAnswer: To pray and offer sacrifice to his Lord alone.

quiz.question: What term did the Prophet's opponents use to mock him, meaning 'cut off'?
options: Al-Masad.
Al-Abtar.
Al-Ma'un.
Al-Fil.
quiz.correctAnswer: Al-Abtar.

vocab.meaning: I do not worship what you worship

content.text: A Clear Distinction in Worship (Verses 1-6)

This Surah was revealed when the disbelievers proposed a compromise: they would alternate between worshipping Allah and the disbelievers' gods. Allah instructs the Prophet to issue a clear and uncompromising rejection, defining the distinct line between Monotheism (Tawheed) and Polytheism (Shirk).

The repeated phrase, **'I do not worship what you worship, nor do you worship what I worship,'** emphasizes the permanent separation of the two forms of worship. The Surah concludes with the final principle of religious integrity: **'You have your way, and I have my Way.'**.

quiz.question: What was the proposal made by the disbelievers that led to the revelation of this Surah?
options: An offer to trade all their goods.
A compromise to alternate between worshipping Allah and their idols.
A demand for the Muslims to leave Makkah.
A challenge to fight a battle.
quiz.correctAnswer: A compromise to alternate between worshipping Allah and their idols.

quiz.question: What is the ultimate principle established by the final verse, 'To you be your religion, and to me be my Way'?
options: The need for forced conversions.
The need for Muslims to change their worship for peace.
The principle of clear distinction and unwavering religious integrity in worship.
The idea that all religions are exactly the same.
quiz.correctAnswer: The principle of clear distinction and unwavering religious integrity in worship.

quiz.question: What concept does this Surah definitively reject?
options: Charity.
Monotheism (Tawheed).
Any form of compromise in the core principles of worship and belief.
The use of the Arabic language.
quiz.correctAnswer: Any form of compromise in the core principles of worship and belief.

vocab.meaning: Allah's ultimate help and the victory over Mecca
glorify the praises of your Lord and seek His forgiveness

content.text: The Prophecy of Victory (Verses 1-2)

This is one of the last complete Surahs revealed. It prophesies the imminent **'Victory of Allah'** (Al-Fath), understood as the Conquest of Makkah. This victory would be accompanied by the sight of people embracing Allah's Way in crowds.
The Instruction for Conclusion (Verse 3)

Following this great achievement, the Prophet (PBUH) is instructed to conclude his mission by increasing his worship and seeking forgiveness: **'then glorify the praises of your Lord and seek His forgiveness, for certainly He is ever Accepting of Repentance.'** This teaches that success should be met with humility and gratitude.

quiz.question: What major event is primarily referred to as 'the Victory' (Al-Fath) in this Surah?
options: The Battle of Badr.
The Conquest of Makkah.
The Prophet's night journey.
The Battle of Uhud.
quiz.correctAnswer: The Conquest of Makkah.

quiz.question: The people entering the religion are described as coming in what manner?
options: One by one.
In secret.
In crowds (Afwājan).
Only the poor people.
quiz.correctAnswer: In crowds (Afwājan).

quiz.question: What two acts of devotion is the believer instructed to increase upon achieving great success?
options: Building large houses and traveling.
Glorifying the praises of their Lord and seeking His forgiveness.
Sleeping and resting.
Arguing and debating with others.
quiz.correctAnswer: Glorifying the praises of their Lord and seeking His forgiveness.

vocab.meaning: May the hands of Abu Lahab perish, and he himself perish
the carrier of thorny kindling (His wife, Umm Jameel)
Neither his wealth nor worldly gains will benefit him

content.text: A Prophecy of Doom (Verses 1-5)

This Surah is a severe and unique condemnation directed at the Prophet's uncle, **Abu Lahab**, and his wife, Umm Jameel, for their intense hostility and active efforts to harm the Prophet. It is the only Surah in the Qur'an that names a specific opponent.

The Surah prophecies that his wealth will not benefit him and he will burn in a flaming Fire. His wife is condemned as the 'carrier of thorny kindling,' who will have a rope of palm-fibre around her neck. The story paradoxically proves the truth of the Qur'an, as Abu Lahab's refusal to accept Islam confirmed the prophecy of his punishment.

quiz.question: What is the key lesson about wealth and worldly gains in this Surah?
options: Wealth is the primary way to enter Paradise.
Wealth can save a person from Hellfire.
Wealth and worldly gains are of no benefit in the Hereafter.
Wealth should be hoarded in this life.
quiz.correctAnswer: Wealth and worldly gains are of no benefit in the Hereafter.

quiz.question: What two individuals are the specific subjects of condemnation in this Surah?
options: Pharaoh and Haman.
Abu Jahl and Al-Walid.
Abu Lahab and his wife, Umm Jameel.
The Prophet's two friends.
quiz.correctAnswer: Abu Lahab and his wife, Umm Jameel.

quiz.question: The condemnation of Abu Lahab is often cited to prove what concept?
options: The importance of family lineage.
The certainty of prophecy, as his fate was sealed before his death.
The need to change one's name.
The weakness of the Arabs.
quiz.correctAnswer: The certainty of prophecy, as his fate was sealed before his death.

vocab.meaning: The Sustainer needed by all (Eternal Refuge)
He has never had offspring, nor was He born
equals reading one-third of the Qur'an

content.text: The Purest Monotheism (Tawheed) (Verses 1-4)

This Surah was revealed when the disbelievers asked the Prophet to describe his Lord. It is the most concise statement of Islamic Monotheism (Tawheed) and is said to be equivalent in reward to reciting **one-third of the Qur'an**.

items: **1. He is Allah, One and Indivisible (Ahad)**.
**2. Allah is The Sustainer needed by all (As-Samad)**.
**3. He neither begets nor is born** (Negating any form of lineage).
**4. There is none comparable to Him (Kufūwan Ahad)**.

content.text: Understanding who Allah is is fundamental to believing in Him, and knowing what Allah is not is as important as knowing what He is.

quiz.question: What does the attribute 'As-Samad' (Eternal Refuge) fundamentally mean?
options: That Allah is always angry.
That Allah is the Sustainer needed by all.
That Allah has a large family.
That Allah is always visible.
quiz.correctAnswer: That Allah is the Sustainer needed by all.

quiz.question: The Prophet (PBUH) described the recitation of Surah Al-Ikhlas as being equivalent to what?
options: Reciting the entire Qur'an once.
Reciting one-half of the Qur'an.
Reciting one-third of the Qur'an.
Reciting ten chapters of the Qur'an.
quiz.correctAnswer: Reciting one-third of the Qur'an.

quiz.question: The phrase 'He neither begets nor is born' refutes which major theological claim?
options: The idea that humans can fly.
The concept of polytheism.
The idea that Allah has a partner, offspring, or was created.
The belief in life after death.
quiz.correctAnswer: The idea that Allah has a partner, offspring, or was created.

vocab.meaning: the evil of the night when it grows dark
those 'witches' casting spells by blowing onto knots

content.text: Seeking Refuge from External Evils (Verses 1-5)

This Surah is part of **Al-Mu'awwidhatayn** (The Two Seekers of Refuge). It is a plea to the Lord of Daybreak for protection against various types of external evils. This Surah, along with An-Nas, was part of the Prophet's treatment when he was affected by a spell.

items: **1. The evil of creation** in general.
**2. The evil of the night when it grows dark** (when crimes and lurking evils occur).
**3. The evil of the casters of spells** (witches) by blowing onto knots.
**4. The evil of the envier** when they envy.

content.text: The believer must always seek Allah's help to repel evil, as He is the only one who can aid and protect against the various forms of evil that exist.

quiz.question: What is the collective name for Surah Al-Falaq and Surah An-Nas?
options: Al-Hamdayn.
Al-Mu'awwidhatayn (The Two Seekers of Refuge).
As-Sāhūn.
Al-Mutaffifin.
quiz.correctAnswer: Al-Mu'awwidhatayn (The Two Seekers of Refuge).

quiz.question: What specific act of witchcraft is mentioned in the Surah?
options: Making dolls and statues.
Blowing onto knots to cast spells.
Speaking in a secret language.
Walking backward in the dark.
quiz.correctAnswer: Blowing onto knots to cast spells.

quiz.question: What is one reason for seeking refuge from the 'night when it grows dark'?
options: It is the only time to pray.
It is when the moon is visible.
It is the time when crimes and lurking evils typically occur.
It is when all the angels descend.
quiz.correctAnswer: It is the time when crimes and lurking evils typically occur.

vocab.meaning: who whispers into the hearts of humankind

content.text: Seeking Refuge from Internal Evil (Waswās) (Verses 1-6)

The final Surah commands the believer to seek refuge in Allah using His three Divine titles—Lord, King, and God of mankind—to emphasize His complete authority. The focus of protection here is from the subtle, internal evil of **Al-Waswās al-Khannās (The Lurking Whisperer)**.

This is the devil who whispers doubt and temptation into the chests/hearts of men. The sources of this evil influence are identified as coming from 'among jinn and humankind'. The Surah is the perfect conclusion, protecting the heart and mind from internal corruption.

quiz.question: What are the three divine titles used to seek refuge in Allah in Surah An-Nas?
options: The Forgiving, The Merciful, The King.
The Creator, The Fashioner, The Sustainer.
Lord of Mankind, King of Mankind, and God of Mankind.
The First, The Last, The Manifest.
quiz.correctAnswer: Lord of Mankind, King of Mankind, and God of Mankind.

quiz.question: What is the primary danger that the believer seeks protection from in Surah An-Nas?
options: A devastating flood.
The evil of the lurking whisperer (Waswās) who whispers into the hearts.
The shame of poverty.
The physical pain of fire.
quiz.correctAnswer: The evil of the lurking whisperer (Waswās) who whispers into the hearts.

quiz.question: The sources of the whispering evil (Waswās) are identified as coming from whom?
options: Only the envier.
Only past prophets.
Only animals and birds.
From among jinn and humankind.
quiz.correctAnswer: From among jinn and humankind.

courses.courseDescription: A foundational course introducing the specialized science of Mustalah al-Hadith, which established the criteria for authenticating, classifying, and preserving the Prophetic tradition (Sunnah).
whatYouWillLearn: The definition and distinction between Hadith, Sunnah, and related technical terms.
The two essential components of any Hadith: Sanad (chain) and Matn (text).
The major classifications of Hadith based on the number of narrators (Tawātur and Āhād).
The major classifications of Hadith based on authenticity (Sahīh, Hasan, and Da'īf).
The methods and criteria used in the rigorous assessment of narrators (Jarh wa Ta'dīl).

vocab.meaning: Hadith (A specific report about the Prophet)
As-Sunnah (The normative way or example of the Prophet)

content.text: The Need for Hadith Terminology

The science of Mustalah al-Hadith developed after the early centuries of Islam to protect the Sunnah from fabrication and error. Its fundamental purpose is to establish the criteria necessary to distinguish genuine Prophetic reports from flawed or fabricated ones.
Distinguishing Hadith, Sunnah, and Athar

items: **Hadith:** Refers to a specific saying, action, tacit approval, or description related to the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).
**Sunnah:** Represents the broader, normative tradition or way of life exemplified by the Prophet. A Hadith is a textual report of the Sunnah.
**Athar:** Generally refers to reports traced back to the Companions (Sahābah) or the generation that followed them (Tābi'ūn), though sometimes used synonymously with Hadith.

content.text: Ibn al-Mubarak said, 'The Sanad is part of the religion. Had it not been for the Sanad, anyone could have said anything they wanted.' This illustrates the fundamental importance of authenticating the source.

quiz.question: What is the primary function of the science of Mustalah al-Hadith?
options: To gather all historical reports about the Arabs.
To establish the criteria for assessing the authenticity of Prophetic traditions.
To translate all Hadith into different languages.
To interpret the complex verses of the Qur'an.
quiz.correctAnswer: To establish the criteria for assessing the authenticity of Prophetic traditions.

quiz.question: In the technical terminology of Hadith, to whom does the term 'Athar' usually refer?
options: Reports from the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) only.
Reports from the Companions and Successors.
Reports found in the Sahihayn only.
Reports containing theological opinions.
quiz.correctAnswer: Reports from the Companions and Successors.

sections.sectionTitle: The Anatomy of a Hadith: Sanad and Matn

vocab.meaning: Al-Isnād (The process of relating the Hadith back to its source)

content.text: Al-Sanad: The Chain of Authority

The **Sanad** is the most crucial part of Hadith authentication. It is the continuous chain of narrators linking the final compiler (e.g., Imam Bukhari) back to the Prophet (PBUH). The entire science of Hadith terminology centers on scrutinizing the integrity and memory of the individuals within this chain.
Al-Matn: The Content

The **Matn** is the actual text, saying, action, or description conveyed by the chain. While the Sanad must be sound, the Matn is also subject to internal criticism to ensure it does not contradict established, stronger texts or clear verses of the Qur'an.
A Hadith is only as strong as its weakest link. If any narrator in the chain (Sanad) is deemed unreliable, the entire report (Matn) is invalidated.

quiz.question: What does the term 'Matn' refer to in the context of Hadith?
options: The individual who transmitted the report.
The book in which the Hadith is recorded.
The actual text, saying, or content of the report.
The grading given to the Hadith (e.g., Sahīh).
quiz.correctAnswer: The actual text, saying, or content of the report.

quiz.question: Why is the continuous chain of narrators (Sanad) considered the 'most crucial' part of a Hadith?
options: It determines the length of the Matn.
Its reliability dictates the authenticity of the entire report.
It is necessary for reading the Arabic text correctly.
It allows for memorizing the Hadith more easily.
quiz.correctAnswer: Its reliability dictates the authenticity of the entire report.

sections.sectionTitle: Classification by Number of Narrators (Tawātur vs. Āhād)

vocab.meaning: Gharīb (Scarce/Lone Hadith - 1 narrator at some point)

content.text: Mutawātir: Absolute Certainty (Yaqīn)

A **Mutawātir** Hadith is defined by the sheer number of narrators at every stage of the chain. This number must be large enough to completely exclude the possibility of collusion or accidental error. The benefit of this class of Hadith is that it provides absolute certainty (**Yaqīn**) and must be accepted without needing further scrutiny of individual narrators.
Āhād: Single-Chain Reports (Probability/Zann)

The **Āhād** class includes all reports that do not meet the stringent requirements of Mutawātir. It provides a strong degree of probability (**Zann**), but its acceptance is conditional upon proving the reliability of every narrator in its specific chain. It is further categorized by the lowest number of narrators in any stage:

items: **Mashhūr:** Reported by at least three narrators at every stage.
**Azīz:** Reported by at least two narrators at every stage.
**Gharīb:** Reported by only one narrator at any stage of the chain.

content.text: While Mutawātir reports form the bedrock of the most fundamental beliefs and practices, the vast majority of legal rulings (Fiqh) and detailed practices rely upon the carefully scrutinized Āhād reports.

quiz.question: What is the primary benefit or knowledge provided by a Mutawātir Hadith?
options: A weak probability of truth.
A historical record of an event.
Absolute certainty (Yaqīn).
A religious opinion open to debate.
quiz.correctAnswer: Absolute certainty (Yaqīn).

quiz.question: Which subclass of Āhād Hadith is defined by having only a single narrator at some point in its chain?
options: Mashhūr
Azīz
Mursal
Gharīb
quiz.correctAnswer: Gharīb

content.text: The Five Conditions for Sahīh (Sound) Hadith
A Hadith is classified as **Sahīh** (Sound) only if it meets five cumulatively strict conditions:

items: **1. Ittisāl as-Sanad:** Continuous chain of narration (no breaks).
**2. Adālat ar-Rāwī:** Narrators are trustworthy, righteous, and of good character.
**3. Dabt ar-Rāwī:** Narrators are precise and accurate in their preservation (strong memory).
**4. Salāmah min ash-Shudhūdh:** Free from being anomalous (not contradicting a stronger, accepted report).
**5. Salāmah min al-Illah:** Free from any subtle, damaging hidden defects.

content.text: Hasan (Good) and Da'īf (Weak)

A **Hasan** Hadith is identical to a Sahīh Hadith except for one criterion: the narrator's level of precision (**Dabt**) is slightly weaker, though still sufficient to be accepted as legal proof. A **Da'īf** Hadith is any report that fails to meet even one of the five conditions for a Hasan or Sahīh report. It is generally not used as legal evidence, though exceptions exist for virtues and moral exhortation.
The existence of Sahīh and Hasan Hadith provides the necessary evidence (Hujjah) for the Islamic legal system.

quiz.question: What is the key difference that distinguishes a Hasan Hadith from a Sahīh Hadith?
options: A Hasan Hadith has a broken chain of narration.
The narrator's righteousness ('Adālah) is weak in a Hasan Hadith.

sections.sectionTitle: Jarh wa Ta'dīl: The Science of Narrator Criticism

content.text: The Purpose of Jarh wa Ta'dīl

This specialized discipline is the foundation of Hadith authentication. It involves meticulous research into the life, behavior, and memory of every narrator in the chain to determine if their report should be accepted. Acceptance requires meeting two primary conditions: **Al-'Adālah (Integrity)** and **Al-Dabt (Precision)**.
The Criteria: Integrity ('Adālah) and Precision (Dabt)

items: **Al-'Adālah (Integrity):** Deals with the narrator's moral character, righteousness, adherence to religious law, and honesty. A narrator is rejected if accused of lying, excessive sin, or major innovation.

**Al-Dabt (Precision):** Deals with the narrator's cognitive ability to remember and transmit the Hadith exactly as they heard it, without error, change, or carelessness. Weakness in Dabt results in a Hadith being labeled Hasan (if slight) or Da'īf (if severe).

content.text: A narrator must be both righteous in character ('Ādil) and accurate in memory (Dābit) for their Hadith to be considered sound (Sahīh) or good (Hasan).

Their ability to write poetry.

quiz.question: What is the primary difference between Al-'Adālah and Al-Dabt?

Al-'Adālah refers to moral integrity/righteousness, and Al-Dabt refers to accuracy/precision of memory.

quiz.correctAnswer: Al-'Adālah refers to moral integrity/righteousness, and Al-Dabt refers to accuracy/precision of memory.
